content:
Room unscramble - Starter layout

Can you spot what's wrong and fix the page?

Room unscramble - Final Layout

This is the correct layout of the room for creators to recreate.

Open the scrambled room webpage

--- task --- Open the starter project and look at the room that appears. It looks a little... scrambled! 👀 --- /task ---

Something's not quite right…

The tiles are in a grid, but the room image looks mixed up. The pieces are there, but not in the right places. In this project, you are going to figure out how the image tiles work, then rearrange the HTML to fix the room! 🛠️ Take a look at this part of the code:
--- code --- --- language: html filename: index.html line_numbers: true line_number_start: 6 line_highlights: 7-12 ---
--- /code ---
What do you notice? - One tile is missing its `alt` text - Another tile has a typo in the filename — it says "tiel" instead of "tile"! 🐞
### Tip You can use the preview panel in the editor to see how your webpage looks as you make changes. Try scrolling down and checking how the tiles appear.
### Debugging If some of the tiles are not showing, check the image `src` paths in the HTML. A small typo in the filename — like `tiel` instead of `tile` — can stop the image from loading!

Find what needs fixing in the code

--- task --- Look closely at the HTML and find what is wrong. There are a few bugs hiding in the code! --- /task ---

Detective mode: activated 🕵️

Let’s inspect the scrambled tiles more carefully. Some things are not quite right — and it's your job to fix them. Have a look at this section of the code:
--- code --- --- language: html filename: index.html line_numbers: true line_number_start: 15 line_highlights: 15 ---
--- /code ---
🪲 Can you spot the problem? One of the `
` elements is missing a closing tag. This can cause the layout to look strange or behave unexpectedly in the grid!
### Tip In an HTML document, every `
` must have a matching `
`. Missing one can cause problems with the layout!
### Debugging If a tile looks like it is inside another tile or not appearing where you expect, check that all `div` tags are correctly closed.

Figure out what the filenames mean

--- task --- Look at the tile image filenames and work out how the names tell you where each tile should go. --- /task ---

A secret code in every filename 🧩

Each tile image has a filename like: ```html bert_sampson_tile_0_1.png ``` Let’s break that down: - `bert_sampson` is the name of the image set - `tile` means it’s part of the grid - The numbers `_0_1` show the **row** and **column** where the tile should go! So `tile_0_1` belongs in **row 0**, **column 1** — that’s the **second tile on the top row**. Here’s an example set of tiles:
--- code --- --- language: html filename: index.html line_numbers: true line_number_start: 7 line_highlights: 7-10 ---
--- /code ---
These are all the tiles in the **top row**, going left to right.
### Tip The grid has **3 rows** and **4 columns** — the tile names help you place them in the correct order!
### Debugging If your layout looks wrong later, check that each tile is in the correct spot based on the numbers in its filename.

Reorder the image tiles

--- task --- Use the tile filenames to rearrange the elements in the correct grid order. --- /task ---

Time to tidy up! 🧼

Now that you understand how the filenames work, you can fix the scrambled grid. Your goal is to arrange the tiles in row order, from top to bottom and left to right. Here’s what the correct layout should look like:
--- code --- --- language: html filename: index.html line_numbers: true line_number_start: 6 line_highlights: 7-18 ---
--- /code ---
Each tag is now in the correct position based on its filename. Nice work! 🧠
### Tip You do not need to change any CSS — just rearrange the order of the tiles inside the
.
### Debugging If your image still looks wrong, double-check the filename numbers and make sure each tile is inside its own
.
